name: 🛠️ Auto n8n Updater (Docker)
description:
### Comment ça fonctionne

Ce flux de travail automatise le processus de vérification et d'application des mises à jour d'une instance n8n auto-hébergée fonctionnant sur Docker. Il s'exécute selon un calendrier, vérifie les nouvelles versions, résume les notes de version avec l'IA et demande votre approbation via Telegram avant de mettre à jour.

1.  **Vérification planifiée :** Le flux de travail s'exécute toutes les heures, déclenché par un nœud `Schedule`.
2.  **Découverte de version :**
    *   Il confirme d'abord qu'il fonctionne dans un environnement Docker.
    *   Il utilise SSH pour se connecter à la machine hôte et inspecte le conteneur n8n en cours d'exécution pour trouver son tag de version actuel (par exemple, `latest` ou `next`).
    *   Il interroge ensuite l'API Docker Hub pour comparer le `digest` de l'image (un ID unique pour une version d'image) de la version en cours d'exécution avec la dernière version disponible pour ce tag.
3.  **Détection de mise à jour :** Si les digests ne correspondent pas, cela signifie qu'une nouvelle image a été poussée pour votre tag de version (par exemple, une nouvelle image `latest` est disponible), et une mise à jour est nécessaire.
4.  **Notes de version alimentées par l'IA :**
    *   Il récupère les notes de version officielles pour la nouvelle version depuis l'API GitHub.
    *   Un modèle d'IA (LLM) résume ces notes techniques en un aperçu concis et lisible par un humain des principales fonctionnalités et corrections.
5.  **Approbation manuelle :** Il envoie un message à un chat Telegram avec le résumé généré par l'IA et deux boutons : "✅ Mettre à jour" et "❌ Ignorer". Le flux de travail se met ensuite en pause et attend votre réponse.
6.  **Exécuter la mise à jour :** Si vous approuvez la mise à jour, le flux de travail utilise SSH pour exécuter une commande `docker compose` sur votre serveur, qui tire la nouvelle image, arrête les anciens conteneurs et démarre les nouveaux.

### Étapes de configuration

**Temps de configuration : ~5-10 minutes**

1.  **Identifiants SSH :**
    *   Allez dans **Identifiants** et créez un nouvel identifiant **SSH** avec le nom d'utilisateur, l'hôte et le mot de passe/clé privée pour le serveur où votre instance n8n Docker fonctionne.
    *   Sélectionnez cet identifiant dans les nœuds **`Get n8n Current Version`** et **`Update Docker`**.
2.  **Identifiants de bot Telegram :**
    *   Créez un bot Telegram et obtenez son token API.
    *   Allez dans **Identifiants** et créez un nouvel identifiant **Telegram** avec le token de votre bot.
    *   Sélectionnez cet identifiant dans le nœud **`Send a text message`**.
3.  **Identifiants de modèle IA :**
    *   Assurez-vous d'avoir des identifiants pour un fournisseur d'IA (comme Google AI, OpenAI, etc.) configurés.
    *   Sélectionnez votre identifiant souhaité dans le nœud **`Google Gemini Chat Model`** (ou remplacez-le par votre nœud LLM préféré).
4.  **Configurer les chemins et les commandes :**
    *   Ouvrez le nœud **`Docker Path`**. Définissez le `docker_path` sur le chemin absolu de votre fichier `docker-compose.yml` sur le serveur (par exemple, `/root/n8n`).
    *   Si vous utilisez des travailleurs, ajustez la `worker_command` pour inclure le bon argument `--scale` pour votre configuration. Sinon, vous pouvez le laisser vide.
5.  **Définissez votre ID de chat :**
    *   Ouvrez le nœud **`Approve Update`** Telegram et entrez votre ID de chat Telegram personnel dans le champ `Chat ID`. Cela garantit que le message d'approbation vous est envoyé.
6.  **Activez le flux de travail.** Il vérifiera maintenant les mises à jour toutes les heures.

**Pour activer des mises à jour entièrement automatiques (sans approbation manuelle) :** Supprimez les nœuds de `Get n8n Releases` à `Approved ?` et connectez le nœud `Needs Update ?` directement au nœud `Update Docker`.

parameters.command: =nohup sh -c "docker compose pull && docker compose down && docker compose up -d {{ $('Docker Path').last().json.worker_command }}" > update.log 2>&1 &

parameters.content:
## ⚠️ MANUAL APPROVAL SECTION

This entire block handles fetching release notes and waiting for your approval on Telegram.

**To enable fully automatic updates**, delete all nodes in this section and connect the `Needs Update ?` node's "true" output directly to the `Update Docker` node.

### 💬 APPROVAL NOTIFICATION

1.  Select your **Telegram Bot** credential.
2.  Set the **Chat ID** to your personal Telegram chat ID to receive the update notifications.

### 🤖 AI Release Summary

These nodes fetch the official release notes and use an AI model to create a simple, easy-to-read summary.

You can replace the Google Gemini node with any other LLM node (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.). The prompt is designed to be robust so feel free to use a small and cheap LLM.

### 🕒 Version Check

This node checks if the new version was published after the last published version checked. This prevents sending duplicate notifications for the same update, as is will only proceed if there is a later publication date.

### 📝 Fetch Release Notes

This node retrieves the official release notes for the new version directly from the n8n GitHub repository API.

This provides the raw content for the AI to summarize. If this node fails (e.g., due to a GitHub API issue), the workflow will still send an update notification but without the detailed summary.

parameters.text:
=<role>
You are an expert technical writer and software release analyst specializing in the n8n automation platform. You have a deep understanding of the n8n user base, which ranges from non-technical business users to experienced developers. Your expertise lies in quickly parsing technical changelogs and identifying the changes that have the most significant impact on users.
</rol>

<instructions>
<goal>
Your goal is to analyze raw n8n release notes and extract a concise, human-readable summary of the most important changes. The summary should be easily digestible for n8n users and developers, highlighting only the key new features, critical fixes, and major enhancements.
</goal>

<context>
The n8n release notes are provided in a markdown-like format, typically generated from GitHub. They are structured with headings like `### Features`, `### Bug Fixes`, and `### Enhancements`.

Your task is to prioritize the information based on its impact:
1.  **Highest Priority:** New Features (especially new nodes or major core functionalities) and Breaking Changes.
2.  **High Priority:** Significant Enhancements to existing popular nodes or core platform capabilities.
3.  **Medium Priority:** Critical Bug Fixes, especially those related to security (XSS, authorization), data integrity, or core execution failures.
4.  **Low Priority (to be ignored):** Minor bug fixes, documentation updates, internal refactoring, dependency updates, or changes to very niche nodes.

You must filter out the noise and focus only on what a user *needs* to know about the new version.
</context>

<examples>
<example_1>
<inputs>
<release_notes>
### [1.99.1](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/compare/n8n@1.99.0...n8n@1.99.1) (2025-06-19)


### Bug Fixes

* **core:** Fix pdf extract not working ([#16463](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/issues/16463)) ([0d69ea4](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/commit/0d69ea4f5bdd1216bd06ad5ae4e60eec6cc948b3))
* **core:** Prevent unauthorised workflow termination ([#16405](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/issues/16405)) ([e5edc60](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/commit/e5edc60e344924230baafb11fa1f0af788e9ca9a))
* **n8n Form Node:** Prevent XSS with video and source tags ([#16329](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/issues/16329)) ([7940384](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/commit/7940384a85041a1890b1203d69c092c887312500))
</release_notes>
</inputs>
<output>
This release focuses on important security and stability fixes:
- A critical security vulnerability (XSS) in the n8n Form Node has been patched.
- An issue that could allow unauthorized workflow termination has been resolved.
- The PDF extraction functionality in the core has been fixed.
</output>
</example_1>

<example_2>
<inputs>
<release_notes>
## [1.98.0](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/compare/n8n@1.97.2...n8n@1.98.0) (2025-06-12)


### Features

* **Airtable Trigger Node:** Add new trigger node ([#16201](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/issues/16201)) ([a1b2c3d](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/commit/a1b2c3d...))

### Enhancements

* **Google Sheets Node:** Add 'overwrite' option for writing data ([#16115](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/issues/16115)) ([e4f5g6h](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/commit/e4f5g6h...))

### Bug Fixes

* **UI:** Corrected typo in settings panel ([#16300](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/issues/16300)) ([i7j8k9l](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/commit/i7j8k9l...))
</release_notes>
</inputs>
<output>
Key highlights for this version:
- **New Node:** A new Airtable Trigger node has been introduced, allowing workflows to start based on Airtable record changes.
- **Google Sheets Node:** The node has been enhanced with a new 'overwrite' option when writing data to a sheet.
</output>
</example_2>

<example_3>
<inputs>
<release_notes>
## [1.97.3](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/compare/n8n@1.97.2...n8n@1.97.3) (2025-06-10)


### Chores

* **deps:** update dependency `some-package` to v2.5.1
* **docs:** clarify wording in credentials page
</release_notes>
</inputs>
<output>
This release contains minor maintenance and documentation updates.
</output>
</example_3>
</examples>

<output_format>
- A short, unordered bulleted list (using `-`) or a brief paragraph.
- Use clear, benefit-oriented language. (e.g., "You can now..." or "Resolved an issue that caused...").
- Rephrase the technical commit messages into plain English.
- Do not include the version number, date, GitHub issue numbers, or commit hashes in your output.
- If there are no significant changes (e.g., only chores, docs, or minor dependency updates), you MUST output the exact phrase: `This release contains minor maintenance and documentation updates.`
</output_format>
</instructions>

<inputs>
<release_notes>
{{ $json.body }}
</release_notes>
</inputs

parameters.message:
=New n8n Version {{ $('Get n8n Github Release').item.json.name || ""}}

{{ $('Release Overview').last().json.text }}

parameters.content:
### ⚙️ CONFIGURE YOUR SERVER PATHS HERE

*   **`docker_path`**: Set this to the **absolute path** on your server where your `docker-compose.yml` file is located.
    *   Example: `/home/user/n8n-docker`
*   **`worker_command`**: If you use n8n workers, set the scale command here (e.g., `--scale n8n-worker=4`). Leave blank if you don't use workers.

### 🔒 SSH Connection

Select your SSH credential for the server hosting your n8n instance in **both** of these nodes.

### 💡 How Update Detection Works

This workflow compares the unique `digest` of your running Docker image with the latest `digest` on Docker Hub for your tag (e.g., `latest`).

If they are different, an update is available.

### 🔎 Get Instance Info

This node fetches local instance settings, like the current version and whether it's running on Docker.

This step ensures the workflow only proceeds if it's on a compatible (Docker) setup. No configuration is needed here.

### 🚀 Final Step: Execute Update

This is the final action node. It connects to your server via SSH and runs the command to update your n8n Docker instance.

**How it works:**
The command performs three key actions:
1.  `docker compose pull`: Downloads the newest n8n image.
2.  `docker compose down`: Safely stops your current n8n containers.
3.  `docker compose up -d`: Starts the new containers in the background.

**Important Details:**
*   **Background Process:** It uses `nohup ... &` to run the update in the background. This is critical because it allows this workflow to finish immediately without waiting for the Docker update to complete, preventing a crash when the docker instance is stopped.
*   **Log File:** Any output or errors from the update process are saved to a file named `update.log` in your n8n Docker directory on the server. **Check this file if you encounter issues after an update.**

user.name: Lucas Peyrin
user.bio:
Innovative builder with a passion for crafting automation solutions that solve real-world challenges. From streamlining workflows to driving efficiency, my work empowers teams and individuals to achieve more with less effort. Experienced in developing scalable tools and strategies that deliver results with n8n, supabase and cline.

Join the N8N Academy:

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
